questions.text: A female singer with hoarseness of voice, unable to sing higher frequency notes. Bowed and depressed unilateral vocal cord is seen. Which muscle is involved? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cricothyroid

  

The cricothyroid muscle is responsible for tensing the vocal cords, which allows for the production of higher frequency sounds. When the vocal cords are tightly stretched, they vibrate at a higher frequency, which is necessary for producing high-pitched notes.

 

In this scenario, the female singer is unable to sing higher frequency notes, indicating that her vocal cords are not adequately tense. This suggests paralysis of the cricothyroid muscle, which normally maintains the tension of the vocal cords. If the cricothyroid muscle is paralyzed, typically due to damage to the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve, the vocal cords become bowed, loose, and floppy, impairing the ability to produce high-frequency sounds.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Posterior cricoarytenoid: This muscle is the only abductor of the vocal cords, which means it separates the vocal cords during breathing. It does not contribute to tensing the vocal cords for high-frequency sound production.

 

Option B. Thyroarytenoid: This muscle acts as both an adductor and a relaxer of the vocal cords, contributing to lowering the pitch of the voice rather than raising it. It does not tense the vocal cords and, therefore, does not aid in the production of higher frequency notes.

 

Option D. Interarytenoid: This muscle functions as an adductor, helping to bring the vocal cords together. It does not have a role in tensing the vocal cords for higher frequencies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cricothyroid muscle is essential for producing high-frequency notes by tensing the vocal cords. Paralysis of the cricothyroid muscle leads to the inability to produce these higher notes due to a lack of tension in the vocal cords.

questions.text: A patient complained of ear discharge, retro-orbital pain, and visual disturbances. What is the diagnosis: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Petrositis

 

Petrositis, specifically Gradenigo's syndrome, is characterized by a triad of symptoms: deep-seated retro-orbital pain, ear discharge, and sixth nerve palsy causing diplopia (double vision). This condition is a complication of chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) and involves inflammation of the petrous part of the temporal bone, which can impinge on the adjacent cranial nerves.

 

  1. Ear discharge is due to the ongoing infection chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) in the middle ear extending into the petrous apex.
  2. Retro-orbital pain occurs due to involvement of the trigeminal nerve (fifth cranial nerve) as the petrous apex is adjacent to Meckel's cave, where the trigeminal ganglion is located.
  3. Visual disturbances (diplopia) are due to sixth cranial nerve palsy. The abducens nerve passes through Dorello's canal beneath the petrous apex and can be affected by the inflammation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lateral sinus thrombosis: This condition can occur as a complication of middle ear infections but does not typically present with visual disturbances. The symptoms usually include severe headache, fever, and neck stiffness.

 

Option C. Labyrinthitis: This inner ear condition usually presents with vertigo, sensorineural hearing loss, and tinnitus, rather than visual disturbances or retro-orbital pain.

 

Option D. Mastoiditis: An infection of the mastoid bone that often presents with pain and tenderness over the mastoid, fever, ear discharge and conductive hearing loss. It does not typically cause retro-orbital pain or visual disturbances.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gradenigo's syndrome (Petrositis) presents with the triad of ear discharge, retro-orbital pain, and sixth nerve palsy causing visual disturbances. This is due to the spread of chronic ear infection to the petrous apex of the temporal bone, affecting adjacent cranial nerves.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding the treatment of a patient who presented with the following as shown in the image? Earlier the abdominal mass was reducible, but now it has become irreducible. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Umbilical excision with herniorrhaphy

 

The clinical scenario presented is that of an umbilical hernia that was previously reducible but has now become irreducible. This suggests the hernia has become complicated, possibly due to incarceration or strangulation, where the contents are trapped, leading to ischemia or gangrene of the herniated tissue. The overlying skin also appears gangrenous and requires excision.

 

The correct management involves surgical intervention to excise the affected umbilical tissue and perform herniorrhaphy, which is a repair of the hernia without the use of a mesh, particularly when there are complications such as strangulation or infection. The surgical approach must address both the excision of compromised tissue and the closure of the hernial defect to prevent recurrence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Umbilical excision: This option only addresses the excision of the skin and does not treat the underlying hernia. Simply excising the umbilical tissue will not resolve the hernia defect or prevent recurrence, making this option inadequate.

 

Option C. Antibiotics: Antibiotics alone are not a definitive treatment for a hernia. While antibiotics may be used if there is an associated infection, they do not resolve the underlying mechanical problem of a hernia.

 

Option D. Incision and drainage: This procedure is appropriate for abscesses and localized infections but not for hernias. There is no indication of an abscess in this scenario; rather, it is a hernia with possible ischemic or gangrenous changes, requiring surgical repair rather than drainage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of complicated umbilical hernias, especially when the hernia becomes irreducible, surgical intervention with umbilical excision and herniorrhaphy is necessary to repair the hernia and prevent further complications.

questions.text: Which of the following can be prescribed in case of an open angle glaucoma with bronchial asthma? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Latanoprost

 

Latanoprost is a Prostaglandin, PGF2α analog, that acts in glaucoma by increasing the uveoscleral outflow of aqueous humor and is used as a first line drug in patients with open angle glaucoma. It can be safely used in bronchial asthma, as it does not cause bronchospasm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Timolol: Timolol is a beta-blocker that can cause bronchospasm as a systemic side effect. Therefore, it is not recommended for patients with bronchial asthma.

 

Option B. Gemeprost: Gemeprost is a prostaglandin E1 (PGE1) analog used for the termination of pregnancy. It is not relevant for the treatment of glaucoma.

 

Option D. Mannitol infusion: Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic used in the treatment of acute angle-closure glaucoma, not open-angle glaucoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Latanoprost, a prostaglandin F2α analog, is safe and effective for the treatment of open-angle glaucoma in patients with bronchial asthma, as it does not cause bronchospasm.

choices.text: Absence of ipsilateral lower limb proprioception
Absence of fine motor movement of fingers
Absence of contralateral lower limb proprioception

questions.text: A patient met with a road traffic accident and developed a cervical spine injury. The fracture fragment had pierced the lateral aspect of the dorsal column tract. Which of the following findings is seen in this patient?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Absence of ipsilateral arm proprioception

 

Explanation

 

The above clinical scenario depicts transection of the spinal cord in the lateral aspect of the dorsal column would affect the fasciculus cuneatus. This lesion would result in absence of ipsilateral proprioception of the arm.

 

 

The fibers in the dorsal column are arranged in such a manner that the sacral segments are positioned most medially and those from the cervical segments are positioned most laterally.

 

These are:

 

  • ﻿﻿Fasciculus gracilis - carrying sensations from the ipsilateral lower limb
  • ﻿﻿Fasciculus cuneatus - carrying sensations from the ipsilateral upper limb.

 

Fasciculus Gracilis and Cuneatus functions:

 

  1. Fine touch
  2. Tactile localization
  3. Tactile discrimination
  4. Vibration

 

This patient with an injury to the lateral part of the cervical cord's dorsal column tract will have damaged fasciculus cuneatus. This would result in loss of touch, vibration, and proprioception in the arm of the same side of the lesion.

 

function below the level of injury. The clue to solving this question is that the question mentions that the damage is to the lateral aspect of the dorsal column tract.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Absence of ipsilateral lower limb proprioception: This would be seen if the fasciculus gracilis was affected, which is responsible for carrying sensations from the ipsilateral lower limb.

 

Option B. Absence of fine motor movement of fingers: This would be a result of damage to the corticospinal tract, which carries motor information.

 

Option D. Absence of contralateral lower limb proprioception: Proprioception is carried by the dorsal column pathway, and it is affected ipsilaterally.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Damage to the lateral aspect of the dorsal column tract in the cervical spine region results in the loss of ipsilateral arm proprioception due to the involvement of the fasciculus cuneatus. This emphasizes the importance of the dorsal column in carrying proprioceptive and fine tactile information from the upper limbs.

 

Additional Information

 

Brown Sequard Syndrome (Hemi-sectioning of spinal cord)

 

  • I/L loss of Fine touch
  • C/L loss of Pain & Temperature
  • I/L loss of Proprioception
  • I/L motor paralysis

questions.text: A lactating mother is eating only vegetables. Which nutrient deficiency will be seen in her newborn?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vitamin B12

 

Explanation: In this scenario, the lactating mother is following a plant-based diet, consuming only vegetables. Vitamin B12 is a nutrient that is not found in plant sources, making it a potential deficiency for strict vegetarians. As a result, the newborn of this mother is likely to experience a deficiency in vitamin B12.

 

While vitamin D is another nutrient that lacks plant sources, it can be synthesized in the skin through exposure to sunlight. Therefore, a deficiency in vitamin D is less likely in this case compared to vitamin B12.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin B2 (riboflavin) is available in various plant-based sources, such as leafy green vegetables, legumes, and whole grains. Therefore, a deficiency in vitamin B2 is less likely in this scenario.

 

Option B. Vitamin A can be obtained from plant sources in the form of provitamin A carotenoids, which are found in yellow, orange, and green leafy vegetables. As the mother is consuming vegetables, a vitamin A deficiency is less likely.

 

Option D. Iron is present in several plant-based sources, including legumes, whole grains, and leafy green vegetables. While the bioavailability of non-heme iron from plant sources is lower than heme iron from animal sources, a deficiency is less likely if the mother consumes a varied vegetable-based diet.

 

Educational Objective

 

Vitamin B12 is a nutrient that is not found in plant sources, making it a potential deficiency concern for individuals following a strict vegetarian or vegan diet, including lactating mothers and their newborns.

questions.text: A patient is undergoing breast surgery, during which several structures are retracted, as shown in the image. Identify the marked muscle given in the image: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Serratus anterior

 

The serratus anterior muscle is clearly visible and marked in the provided image

 

  • The serratus anterior muscle is located on the lateral aspect of the thoracic wall and plays a critical role in scapular protraction and stabilization.
  • It originates from the first to eighth ribs and inserts on the medial border of the scapula.
  • This muscle is often encountered during breast surgeries, mastectomies, and axillary lymph node dissections, where it may need to be retracted to access deeper structures.
  • Is innervated by the long thoracic nerve (nerve of Bell) 
  • Acts as the "boxer's muscle" as it has punching and pushing ability 
  • Its paralysis leads to winging of scapula

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subscapularis: Incorrect. The subscapularis muscle is part of the rotator cuff muscles and lies deep to the scapula. It is not visible in this view as it is located in Bicipital Groove. Also called as “Forgotten muscle of the Rotator Cuff”

 

Option B. Teres major: Incorrect. It lies posterior wall of axilla, It is not visible in the surgical field during breast surgery

 

Option C. Latissimus dorsi: Incorrect. While the latissimus dorsi muscle is in proximity to the posterior thoracic wall and can be involved in breast reconstruction surgeries (e.g., flap procedures), it does not align with the location or appearance of the marked muscle in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The serratus anterior is a critical muscle encountered in breast surgeries due to its position along the lateral thoracic wall and proximity to the axilla.

choices.text: 60 mg iron and 500 mcg folic acid twice a week

60 mg iron and 500 mcg folic acid daily
