questions.text: What dose of iron and folic acid should an anemic pregnant woman in her 2nd trimester be given? (FMGE JANUARY 2024
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 60 mg iron and 500 mcg folic acid daily

 

Explanation:

 

Under the Anemia Mukt Bharat program, which aims to reduce the prevalence of anemia in India by 3 percentage points every year, the "6 by 6 by 6" strategy is used. This strategy targets 6 beneficiaries, includes 6 interventions, and involves 6 institutional mechanisms.

 

 

One of the interventions is iron and folic acid supplementation.

 

Anemic pregnant women in their second trimester should be given 60 mg of elemental iron and 500 mcg of folic acid daily for 180 days, as per the guidelines of the Anemia Mukt Bharat program.

 

For pregnant women, the recommended dose is 60 mg of elemental iron and 500 mcg of folic acid daily for 180 days during pregnancy. This is provided in the form of red-colored tablets. The same dose is also given to lactating mothers for 180 days post-delivery.

 

If the woman does not respond to this dosage or is anemic, then other forms of iron supplementation, such as ferrous carboxy maltose and IV sucrose, may be considered.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Under the Revised National Tuberculosis Control Programme (RNTCP), what category and color of drug box was designated for sputum smear-positive cases treated after default? [NEET PG 2015]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Category 2, Blue

 

  • The Revised National Tuberculosis Control Programme (RNTCP) categorizes TB patients based on their treatment history and sputum status. Patients who are being treated after default are classified under Category 2. 
  • These retreatment cases receive their medications in patient-wise boxes that are color-coded blue. The blue box contains the full course of treatment for Category 2 patients, with medications packaged in blister packs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Category 1, Red: Category 1 with red boxes is designated for new TB cases (new sputum smear-positive, new sputum smear-negative, and new extrapulmonary TB cases), not for retreatment scenarios like default cases.

 

Option C. Category 2, Yellow: While Category 2 is correct for retreatment cases, the color code for Category 2 boxes is blue, not yellow. There is no yellow color code in the RNTCP treatment regimen.

 

Option D. Category 1, Green: This is incorrect on both counts. Category 1 does not include retreatment cases like default cases, and green is not a designated color for TB treatment boxes in the RNTCP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Retreatment TB patients, including those treated after default, are classified as Category 2 and receive their medications in blue-colored boxes, while new cases (Category 1) receive medications in red-colored boxes.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not accurate concerning a chalazion? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Associated with Severe Pain

 

A chalazion is characterized by being painless rather than painful. Chalazion symptoms include "painless swelling in the eyelid, gradually increasing in size." It is specifically described as a "chronic non-infective (non-suppurative) lipogranulomatous inflammation of the meibomian gland" that develops without significant pain, which contrasts with painful conditions like hordeolum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chronic Onset: Correct statement. Chalazion is defined as a "chronic non-infective lipogranulomatous inflammation" that develops gradually with "painless swelling in the eyelid, gradually increasing in size."

 

Option B. Involvement of the Meibomian Gland: Correct statement. Chalazion is specifically described as a "chronic non-infective (non-suppurative) lipogranulomatous inflammation of the meibomian gland."

 

Option D. Characterized by Granulomatous Inflammation: Correct statement. A chalazion is definitively a "lipogranulomatous inflammation."

 

Contrast with painful lid conditions: Unlike chalazion, conditions like hordeolum externum (stye) and hordeolum internum are characterized by "acute pain associated with swelling of the lid." In hordeolum internum, the pain is even described as "more intense, due to the swelling being embedded deeply in the dense fibrous tissue."

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Chalazion is a painless, chronic, lipogranulomatous inflammation of the meibomian gland, which distinguishes it from painful acute lid conditions like hordeolum.

choices.text: Peutz Jegher syndrome
Villous adenoma
Juvenile polyp

questions.text: A 5-year-old child was admitted to the hospital with a history of prolapsing rectal mass and painless rectal bleeding. The histopathological image of the mass is as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Juvenile Polyp

 

The clinical features and the histopathological image showing characteristic cystically dilated crypts and glands are suggestive of a juvenile polyp.

 

  • Juvenile (retention) polyps are mucosal epithelial and lamina propria malformations. These can be sporadic or syndromic, but their morphology is often indistinguishable. The vast majority of juvenile polyps are found in children under the age of five. When found in adults, polyps with the same morphology are sometimes referred to as inflammatory polyps. The majority of juvenile polyps are in the rectum and cause painless rectal bleeding.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Puetz Jegher syndrome: Puetz Jegher syndrome is a rare autosomal dominant syndrome that manifests as multiple GI hamartomatous polyps and mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation at the age of 11 years.

 

 

 

Option B. Villous adenoma: Villous adenomas are neoplastic and present with a different histopathological pattern of finger-like or villous projections.

 

  • They are usually found in older adults and are not typically associated with painless rectal bleeding in children.

 

Option D. Tubular adenoma: Tubular adenomas are intraepithelial neoplasms that can range from small polyps to large sessile lesions.

 

  • They do not exhibit the cystically dilated glands seen in juvenile polyps and are also more common in older adults.

 

Note - Adenomas are intraepithelial neoplasms that range in size from small polyps to large sessile lesions. There is no preference for either gender, and both are present in nearly 50% of adults living in the Western world by age 50. Adenomas can be classified as tubular, tubulovillous, or villous based on their architecture.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Juvenile polyps are the most common type of rectal polyps in children under five, characterized by cystically dilated crypts and glands, and often present with painless rectal bleeding.

questions.text: On a histopathological slide of an atherosclerotic plaque, what does the presence of needle-shaped empty spaces indicate? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Cholesterol Cleft

 

Explanation: 

 

In atherosclerotic plaques, the characteristic needle-shaped empty spaces observed on histopathology represent cholesterol clefts. These spaces form when cholesterol crystals are dissolved during routine tissue processing, leaving behind characteristic empty clefts. They are typically found in the necrotic core of the atherosclerotic plaque, alongside foam cells, necrotic debris, fibrin, and other plasma proteins. These crystalline cholesterol deposits contribute to the "grumous" (soft and friable) nature of the lipid core in advanced atheromas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Foam Cells - These are lipid-laden macrophages and smooth muscle cells found in atherosclerotic plaques, but they appear as cells with foamy cytoplasm due to accumulated lipid droplets, not as empty needle-shaped spaces. Foam cells are a key feature of atherosclerotic lesions, particularly in early fatty streaks.

 

Option C. Smooth Muscle Cells - These cells are present in atherosclerotic plaques, particularly in the fibrous cap, but they appear as spindle-shaped cells with nuclei, not as empty spaces. Smooth muscle cells play an important role in plaque stabilization through ECM production.

 

Option D. Glycogen - Glycogen deposits appear as clear spaces within cell cytoplasm but have a different morphology than cholesterol clefts and are not typically a prominent feature of atherosclerotic plaques. Glycogen is more commonly observed in glycogen storage diseases or in certain liver pathologies.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Cholesterol clefts, appearing as characteristic needle-shaped empty spaces in histopathology, are hallmark features of advanced atherosclerotic plaques, representing crystalline cholesterol deposits that have been dissolved during tissue processing.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a risk factor for ectopic pregnancy? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Condom

 

Condom is not a risk factor for ectopic pregnancy. Rather, barrier methods like condoms provide contraception without altering tubal anatomy or function. While there are numerous documented risk factors for ectopic pregnancy including various contraceptive methods, condoms do not appear among these established risk factors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Oral contraceptive pills (OCP): Incorrect. Use of progestin-only pills or postcoital estrogen preparations increases the chance of tubal pregnancy, likely due to impaired tubal motility. OCPs can alter tubal function, potentially increasing risk when contraception fails.

 

Option C. Intrauterine device (IUD): Incorrect. IUDs are associated with increased risk of ectopic pregnancy. While they effectively prevent intrauterine pregnancy, they prevent tubal implantation to a lesser extent. There is a relative increase in tubal pregnancy (7 times more) should pregnancy occur with an IUD in situ. The relative risk varies by IUD type: Progestasert > LNG-IUD > Copper IUD.

 

Option D. Tubal ligation: Incorrect. This is a significant risk factor. There is a 15-50% chance of pregnancy being ectopic if conception occurs after sterilization failure. Tubal surgery (either for sterilization or fertility restoration) represents one of the highest risk factors for ectopic pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While barrier methods like condoms have no effect on ectopic pregnancy risk, hormonal contraceptives, IUDs, and surgical procedures involving the fallopian tubes significantly increase the risk of ectopic implantation due to their effects on tubal function, anatomy, or motility.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male presents with headache, confusion, visual disturbances, nausea, vomiting, and seizures. On examination, blood pressure is 220/110 mmHg. Which of the following treatments is most appropriate for managing his condition? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) IV Labetalol

 

This case presents a hypertensive emergency with signs of hypertensive encephalopathy, as indicated by the symptoms of headache, confusion, visual disturbances, nausea, vomiting, and seizures, along with severely elevated blood pressure (220/110 mmHg). In hypertensive emergencies, the goal is to rapidly reduce blood pressure using intravenous medications to prevent further organ damage.

 

IV Labetalol is a preferred treatment in hypertensive emergencies, especially those involving encephalopathy. Labetalol is a combined alpha and beta-blocker that can reduce blood pressure quickly and effectively, making it ideal for this scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral Nifedipine: Oral nifedipine is not appropriate for hypertensive emergencies because it does not act rapidly enough, and oral medications are generally avoided in such acute settings.

 

Option B. Oral Nicardipine capsules: Like oral nifedipine, oral nicardipine is not suitable for emergencies due to its slower onset of action. Nicardipine is more effective in its intravenous form for such cases.

 

Option C. IV Nitroglycerine: Although IV nitroglycerine can be used in hypertensive emergencies, it is not the best choice for hypertensive encephalopathy. Nitroglycerine is more commonly used in cases involving acute coronary syndromes or pulmonary edema, but it is usually avoided in patients with CNS involvement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DOC for Hypertensive emergencies:

 

  • Encephalopathy - Nicardipine or IV Labetalol

  • Intracranial Hemorrhage - Nicardipine or Labetalol

  • Acute Coronary Syndrome – IV Nitroglycerin

  • Pulmonary Edema - Intravenous Nitroglycerin / Sodium Nitroprusside

  • Aortic Dissection – Nicardipine in combination with Esmolol or Labetalol

  • In Pregnancy - Labetalol

questions.text: A child presents to the emergency department with a history of ingestion of 10-20 ferrous sulfate tablets. Arterial blood gas revealed acidosis. Which of the following can be used in the management of this condition? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Whole Bowel Irrigation

 

The child has ingested a significant amount of ferrous sulfate, leading to iron intoxication, which has resulted in metabolic acidosis. Managing iron overdose requires specific interventions.

 

Key Points:

 

  1. Iron Intoxication: Iron overdose is a common pediatric poisoning that can lead to significant morbidity and mortality. Ingesting a large number of ferrous sulfate tablets can result in gastrointestinal irritation, systemic toxicity, and metabolic acidosis.
  2. Arterial Blood Gas (ABG) Revealed Acidosis: Metabolic acidosis is a severe consequence of iron poisoning, indicating systemic toxicity.

 

Management of Iron Intoxication:

 

  • Whole Bowel Irrigation (WBI): This is a key intervention for decontaminating the gastrointestinal tract in cases of iron overdose. WBI is performed using a polyethylene glycol-electrolyte solution to flush out the gastrointestinal contents. It is particularly useful when iron tablets are visible on an abdominal X-ray.

 

Antidote: The specific antidote for iron poisoning is deferoxamine, which binds free iron and promotes its excretion. While deferoxamine is essential in managing iron toxicity, it is not listed as an option in this question.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Activated Charcoal: As mentioned, it is not effective for iron, alcohols, acids, alkalis, or petroleum product intoxications. Activated charcoal does not adsorb iron, making it unsuitable for treating iron overdose.

 

Option C. Dimercaprol: Used for heavy metal poisoning like arsenic, gold, and mercury, but not effective for iron.

 

Option D. Penicillamine: Used primarily for heavy metal poisoning like copper and lead, and ineffective for iron.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Whole Bowel Irrigation with polyethylene glycol is the preferred method for managing iron tablet ingestion, especially when iron tablets are visible on an abdominal X-ray.

questions.text: Lactulose is ? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Galactose and fructose

 

Lactulose is a synthetic disaccharide used primarily as a laxative and in the treatment of hepatic encephalopathy. It is composed of:

 

  • Galactose: A monosaccharide commonly found in dairy products.
  • Fructose: A monosaccharide found in many plants, where it is often bonded to glucose to form the disaccharide sucrose.

 

Lactulose is different from lactose, which is a natural disaccharide found in milk and composed of galactose and glucose.

 

Comparison with Other Disaccharides:

  • Lactose: Galactose + Glucose (found in milk, with a beta bond)
  • Maltose: Glucose + Glucose (alpha 1,4 bond)
  • Isomaltose: Glucose + Glucose (alpha 1,6 bond)
  • Trehalose: Glucose + Glucose (alpha 1,1 bond)
  • Sucrose: Glucose + Fructose (table sugar, with an alpha bond)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lactulose is composed of galactose and fructose, differentiating it from lactose, which is made up of galactose and glucose. It is commonly used for its medicinal properties, particularly as a laxative.

questions.text: Which ion channels are defective in CFTR gene mutation? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cl-

 

The CFTR (Cystic Fibrosis Transmembrane Conductance Regulator) gene mutation primarily affects chloride ion channels. In cystic fibrosis, the defective CFTR gene leads to the malfunctioning of these chloride channels, which are crucial for maintaining the balance of salt and water on epithelial surfaces such as the lungs and the pancreas. This malfunction results in the production of thick and sticky mucus, leading to the various symptoms associated with cystic fibrosis. The normal functioning CFTR protein allows chloride ions to move in and out of cells, regulating the water content in mucus and other secretions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Na+: Incorrect. While sodium ion transport can be indirectly affected by the dysfunctional chloride channels, the primary defect in cystic fibrosis is related to chloride ions.

 

Option C. K+: Incorrect. Potassium channels are not directly affected by the CFTR gene mutation. The primary defect is specific to chloride ion channels.

 

Option D. Ca2+: Incorrect. Calcium channels are not directly impacted by mutations in the CFTR gene. The main issue in cystic fibrosis lies with chloride ion transport.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CFTR gene mutations cause defects in chloride ion channels, leading to the symptoms of cystic fibrosis.

questions.text: What is the antihypertensive of choice in a 28-week preeclamptic woman with asthma? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nifedipine

 

Explanation:

 

In managing preeclampsia, labetalol is often the first-line antihypertensive due to its efficacy and safety profile in pregnancy. However, labetalol is both an alpha and beta-blocker, and its use can exacerbate asthma by causing bronchoconstriction. Therefore, it is contraindicated in asthmatic patients.

 

Nifedipine: This is a calcium channel blocker that is safe and effective in pregnancy. It does not have the bronchoconstrictive effects of labetalol, making it the antihypertensive of choice for a preeclamptic woman with asthma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral labetalol and Option B. IV labetalol: Both forms are contraindicated in patients with asthma due to the risk of bronchoconstriction.

 

Option D. Telmisartan: This angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB) is contraindicated in pregnancy because it can cause fetal renal hypoperfusion and oligohydramnios, among other teratogenic effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nifedipine is the antihypertensive of choice in a preeclamptic woman with asthma due to its safety profile and lack of broncho constrictive effects.

questions.text:
Arrange the steps of the Demographic cycle in the correct chronological sequence: [NEET PG 2024]

 

  1. Low stationary
  2. High stationary
  3. Declining
  4. Early expanding
  5. Late expanding
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) 2 4 5 1 3

 

The Demographic Transition Model describes the stages a country goes through as it transitions from high birth and death rates to low birth and death rates. The stages of the demographic cycle in correct chronological order are:

 

2. High Stationary : This is the first stage characterized by high birth and high death rates, leading to a stable population. It reflects pre-industrial societies with limited medical care and poor living conditions.

 

4. Early Expanding: In this stage, death rates start to decline due to improvements in healthcare, sanitation, and nutrition, while birth rates remain high, resulting in rapid population growth.

 

5. Late Expanding : Birth rates begin to fall as societies become more urbanized and access to contraception improves, but the population continues to grow, albeit at a slower rate.

 

1. Low Stationary : Both birth and death rates are low, stabilizing the population size. This stage reflects advanced economies with high living standards and access to family planning.

 

3. Declining : In the final stage, the birth rate falls below the death rate, leading to a declining population. This stage is seen in highly developed countries with aging populations and very low fertility rates.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence of the demographic cycle stages is: High Stationary, Early Expanding, Late Expanding, Low Stationary, and Declining.

questions.text: After how many seconds of chest compressions and bag and mask ventilation, should we start the adrenaline? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 60 seconds

 

Adrenaline is administered during neonatal resuscitation when the heart rate remains below 60 beats per minute after 60 seconds of effective bag and mask ventilation, or if the heart rate remains below 60 despite adequate bag and mask ventilation for 30 seconds. The prompt administration of adrenaline is crucial for improving perfusion and achieving successful resuscitation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adrenaline should be administered when the heart rate is less than 60 beats per minute after 60 seconds of bag and mask ventilation.

questions.text: Identify the condition in the image shown below? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cephal hematoma

 

A cephal hematoma is a collection of blood between the skull and the periosteum and is typically limited by the edges of the skull bones. It does not cross suture lines because the bleeding is confined by the bone edges. This differentiates it from other types of scalp swellings.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Caput succedaneum: Caput succedaneum refers to diffuse swelling of the scalp that crosses the suture lines and extends beyond the presenting part of the baby's head. It is caused by pressure from the birth canal during delivery.

 

Option C. Subgaleal hematoma: A subgaleal hematoma is a collection of blood between the scalp galea aponeurosis and the periosteum of the skull. It typically presents as a diffuse, boggy swelling that can cross suture lines and extend over large areas of the scalp.

 

Option D. None of the above: This option is incorrect as the image and description fit the characteristics of a cephal hematoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A cephal hematoma is a collection of blood between the skull and the periosteum, confined by the bone edges, and does not cross suture lines.

choices.text: Decreased GFR
Has inotropic effect

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding the actions of endothelin-1 except? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Bronchodilation

 

Explanation

 

Contrary to bronchodilation, ET-1 actually causes bronchoconstriction in the lungs, mediated through ET-B receptors. This makes it detrimental in respiratory pathologies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vasoconstriction: Correct and a well-documented action of ET-1.

 

Option C. Decreased GFR: Correct, as ET-1 affects renal blood flow and filtration.

 

Option D. Has inotropic effect: Correct, ET-1 increases the force of heart contractions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Actions of Endothelin-1 (ET-1)

 

  1. On blood vessels - Potent vasoconstrictor, vascular growth, matrix production inflammation → can lead to atherosclerosis, Pulmonary artery hypertension, systemic hypertension
  2. On heart – Inotropic effect, Apoptosis, cardiomyocytes and cardio fibroblast growth and metabolism → can lead to heart failure, cardiac fibrosis, cardiac hypertrophy
  3. In the kidneys - involved in Tubuloglomerular feedback - \ GFR leads to diuresis, natriuresis, glomerular filtration, renal blood flow. Maybe be involved in glomerulosclerosis diabetic nephropathy, polycystic kidney disease, proteinuric diseases, hypertension.
  4. In the lungs, it causes bronchoconstriction (mediated via ET-B receptors)
  5. In the brain, - regulate the transport of substances across blood brain barrier (BBB).
  6. In GIT, they are involved in the migration of myenteric plexus to distal colon (failure leads to Hirschsprung's/megacolon).
  7. Platelet activation
  8. Closure of ductus arteriosus.
  9. Deletion of both alleles of ET-1 gene - craniofacial abnormalities and respiratory failure at birth.

questions.text: Which of the following steps is not included in WHO's STEP approach?[NEET  PG 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Therapeutic assessment

 

  • STEPwise approach to surveillance (STEPS) is a simple, standardized method by WHO for surveillance. It is of two types:
    • STEPwise approach to chronic disease risk factor surveillance
    • STEPwise approach to Stroke surveillance

choices.text: 2-3 hours after a hyperosmolar meal

questions.text: All of the following are true about Delayed or Late Dumping Syndrome, except? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Diarrhea

 

Explanation:

 

Late dumping syndrome is a consequence of peptic ulcer surgery characterized by reactive hypoglycemia occurring typically 1-3 hours after meals. It develops when carbohydrate-rich food causes a rapid rise in blood glucose, triggering an excessive insulin response that leads to subsequent hypoglycemia. Diarrhea is typical of early dumping.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 2-3 hours after hyperosmolar meal - TRUE for late dumping. Late dumping occurs in the second hour after meals, typically 1-3 hours post-meal. The timing is correct.

 

Option B. Reactive hypoglycemia - TRUE for late dumping. Late dumping is defined as reactive hypoglycemia caused by the carbohydrate load in the small bowel, leading to a rise in plasma glucose, which triggers insulin release and subsequent hypoglycemia.

 

Option D. Neuroglucopenic symptoms are prominent - TRUE for late dumping. The symptoms of late dumping include tremor, faintness, prostration, dizziness, and palpitations, which are manifestations of hypoglycemia.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Late dumping syndrome presents 1-3 hours after meals with hypoglycemic symptoms (tremors, faintness, dizziness) due to reactive hypoglycemia, while diarrhea is characteristic of early dumping syndrome which occurs immediately after meals.

 

 

Features of Early and Late Dumping

questions.text: The Pentose Phosphate Pathway is significant for the synthesis of: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Both B and C

 

Explanation:

 

The pentose phosphate pathway serves two major functions: 

 

  1. The formation of NADPH for synthesis of fatty acids and steroids, and maintaining reduced glutathione for antioxidant activity.
  2. The synthesis of ribose for nucleotide and nucleic acid formation. The pathway has two phases - an oxidative phase that generates NADPH, and a nonoxidative phase that is responsible for ribose-5-phosphate synthesis, which is the precursor for nucleotides.

 

The pentose phosphate pathway is especially important in tissues requiring NADPH for reductive syntheses (like liver, adipose tissue, adrenal cortex, erythrocytes, testis, and lactating mammary gland) and in all cells requiring ribose for nucleotide synthesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ATP: The pentose phosphate pathway does not lead to formation of ATP. It is an alternative route for glucose metabolism that serves other purposes besides energy production.

 

Option B and C individually: While each of these options mentions one of the functions of the pentose phosphate pathway, neither is complete by itself. The pathway definitively serves both purposes - generating NADPH and producing ribose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pentose phosphate pathway has dual importance in metabolism: generating NADPH for reductive biosynthesis and antioxidant defense, while also providing essential ribose-5-phosphate for nucleotide synthesis, without producing ATP like glycolysis does.

questions.text: Patient after road traffic accident was brought to the emergency. His pulse rate was 50 beats per minute, blood pressure was 80/60 mm of Hg. On evaluation his ECG was normal, eFAST was negative, and chest X-ray was normal. This status of the patient could be best classified under which type of shock?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Neurogenic shock

 

Explanation

 

Neurogenic shock is a type of distributive shock resulting from the loss of sympathetic tone due to spinal cord injury, often seen in trauma cases like road traffic accidents. This leads to hypotension due to vasodilation and bradycardia due to unopposed vagal tone.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Hemorrhagic shock: Characterized by tachycardia and clinical signs of bleeding. The normal eFAST and chest X-ray, along with bradycardia, make this unlikely.

 

Option B. Cardiogenic shock: Expected to show ECG changes and usually presents with tachycardia.

 

Option D. Anaphylactic shock: Typically presents with tachycardia, urticaria, and respiratory symptoms due to allergen exposure.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

Neurogenic shock should be suspected in trauma patients with hypotension and bradycardia, especially when there is no evidence of hemorrhage or other common shock etiologies.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-diabetic drug is associated with increased risk of urinary tract infections? (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dapagliflozin

 

Dapagliflozin is a sodium-glucose cotransporter-2 (SGLT2) inhibitor. SGLT2 inhibitors work by promoting the excretion of glucose through the urine. This increased urinary glucose can create an environment that promotes the growth of bacteria, thereby increasing the risk of urinary tract infections. This class of drugs is well known for its association with UTIs and genital infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pioglitazone: Pioglitazone is a thiazolidinedione that improves insulin sensitivity. It is not associated with an increased risk of urinary tract infections. Common side effects include weight gain, edema, and an increased risk of heart failure.

 

Option C. Sitagliptin: Sitagliptin is a dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitor. It works by increasing incretin levels, which in turn increase insulin secretion and decrease glucagon secretion. Sitagliptin is not commonly associated with an increased risk of urinary tract infections.

 

Option D. Metformin: Metformin is a biguanide that decreases hepatic glucose production and improves insulin sensitivity. It is not associated with an increased risk of urinary tract infections. Common side effects of metformin include gastrointestinal disturbances such as diarrhea and abdominal discomfort.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In summary, dapagliflozin, an SGLT2 inhibitor, is associated with an increased risk of urinary tract infections due to its mechanism of increasing glucose excretion in the urine. This patient’s recurrent UTIs could be related to her use of dapagliflozin.

questions.text: Which structure develops from the 6th pharyngeal arch artery on the left side? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ductus arteriosus

 

The 6th pharyngeal arch artery plays a crucial role in embryonic development, particularly in forming structures related to the circulatory system. On the left side, the distal part of the 6th pharyngeal arch artery develops into the ductus arteriosus, a vital fetal blood vessel that allows blood to bypass the lungs, which are not yet functional before birth. After birth, the ductus arteriosus normally closes and becomes the ligamentum arteriosum.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Arch of aorta: The arch of the aorta is primarily derived from the left 4th pharyngeal arch artery, not the 6th.

 

Option C. Subclavian artery: The right subclavian artery is derived from the right 4th pharyngeal arch artery and other structures, while the left subclavian artery arises from the left 7th intersegmental artery.

 

Option D. Common carotid artery: The common carotid artery primarily arises from the 3rd pharyngeal arch artery, not the 6th.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ductus arteriosus, a critical structure in fetal circulation, develops from the distal part of the 6th pharyngeal arch artery on the left side.

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about cutaneous anthrax, except: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Wool Sorter's disease

 

Explanation:

 

Wool Sorter's disease is NOT a feature of cutaneous anthrax but rather refers to pulmonary anthrax. Wool Sorter's disease is specifically the inhalational form of anthrax that occurs when spores are inhaled, typically among workers handling contaminated wool, hides, or other animal products. It affects the respiratory system, presenting with flu-like symptoms that progress to severe respiratory distress, and has historically had a very high mortality rate (approaching 100% if untreated).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Malignant pustule - This statement is true about cutaneous anthrax. The characteristic lesion of cutaneous anthrax is known as a "malignant pustule." This term describes the central necrotic, painless lesion that develops at the site of inoculation after spores enter through breaks in the skin.

 

Option B. Hide Porter's disease - This statement is true about cutaneous anthrax. "Hide Porter's disease" is another name for cutaneous anthrax, named after the occupational risk faced by workers who carried (ported) animal hides, which could be contaminated with anthrax spores.

 

Option C. Black eschar - This statement is true about cutaneous anthrax. The development of a black eschar is the hallmark of cutaneous anthrax. The lesion begins as a painless papule that vesiculates and eventually develops into a characteristic black, necrotic eschar surrounded by non-pitting edema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The three forms of anthrax have distinct clinical presentations and names: cutaneous anthrax (Hide Porter's disease, malignant pustule) presents with a characteristic painless black eschar; pulmonary anthrax (Wool Sorter's disease) presents with respiratory symptoms; and gastrointestinal anthrax affects the digestive tract after consuming contaminated meat.

questions.text: An old man has recurrent fainting episodes. His ECG shows P-waves at 75/min, QRS complexes are at 35 bpm. The clinical diagnosis is: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Stokes-Adams Syndrome

 

The patient has recurrent fainting episodes, and his ECG shows a discrepancy between the rate of P-waves (75/min) and QRS complexes (35 bpm), indicating an AV block.

 

In this case, the P-waves are getting blocked at the AV node, leading to fewer QRS complexes.

 

Stokes-Adams Syndrome refers to recurrent fainting/ syncopal episodes caused by sudden fluctuations in cardiac output, paroxysmal Bradycardia often due to AV blocks such as complete heart block or second-degree AV block (Mobitz type II).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Electrical alternans: This is seen in cardiac tamponade and is characterized by beat-to-beat variations in QRS amplitude or axis. The patient would present with signs of tamponade such as hypotension, muffled heart sounds, and jugular venous distension, which is not the case here.

 

Option B. Atrial tachycardia: This would present with a ventricular response rate of more than 100 bpm and would typically involve abnormal P-wave morphology. The patient in this case has bradycardia (QRS at 35 bpm), excluding atrial tachycardia.

 

Option C. First degree AV block: This is characterized by a prolonged PR interval with a 1:1 P to QRS ratio. The discrepancy between P-wave and QRS complex rates in this case excludes first degree AV block.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Stokes-Adams Syndrome involves recurrent fainting episodes due to sudden changes in cardiac output, typically from AV block-related bradycardia. Recognizing the discrepancy between atrial and ventricular rates is crucial for diagnosis.

choices.text: Release of noradrenaline at synaptic cleft
Selectively and irreversibly inhibits nicotinic receptors

questions.text: An elderly woman received a Botox injection for the treatment of wrinkles.  Which of the following is the mechanism of action of botulinum toxin? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inhibits the release of acetylcholine

 

  • The botulinum toxin works by preventing acetylcholine from entering the synaptic cleft. Acetylcholine is exocytosed by SNARE protein, which is broken down by botulinum toxin. Consequently, it prevents acetylcholine from being released.
  • Other agents that regulate the level of Ach in the synapse are:
    • Hemicholinium acts by inhibiting choline uptake (the rate limiting step in the synthesis of acetylcholine)
    • Vesamicol inhibits the uptake of Acetylcholine into the vesicles.
    • Physostigmine inhibits the breakdown of Ach at the synaptic cleft by the action of Acetylcholine esterase.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Release of noradrenaline at synaptic cleft: Botulinum toxin does not facilitate the release of noradrenaline. Its primary action is on the cholinergic neurons where it inhibits the release of acetylcholine.

 

Option C. Selectively and irreversibly inhibits nicotinic receptors: Botulinum toxin does not directly inhibit nicotinic receptors. Instead, it prevents the release of acetylcholine, which means there is no neurotransmitter available to bind to and activate the nicotinic receptors.

 

Option D. Stimulates muscarinic and nicotinic receptors: Botulinum toxin does not stimulate muscarinic or nicotinic receptors. In fact, it decreases neurotransmission by preventing the release of acetylcholine, which would otherwise stimulate these receptors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Botulinum toxin inhibits the release of acetylcholine by cleaving SNARE proteins, thereby preventing neurotransmission at the neuromuscular junction and leading to muscle relaxation.

questions.text: Which of the following connective tissue degradation disorder is associated with aortic aneurysm? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Marfan's Syndrome

 

Marfan's Syndrome is a connective tissue disorder that affects the body's connective tissues, which provide structural support to various organs and tissues. It is particularly associated with cardiovascular complications, including aortic aneurysms and dissections. This is due to the weakening of the aortic wall caused by defective fibrillin-1, a glycoprotein essential for the elasticity and strength of the connective tissue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome: While Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome (EDS) can lead to vascular complications, including aortic aneurysms, it is specifically the vascular type (Type IV) of EDS that is associated with these issues. However, Marfan's Syndrome is more commonly linked to aortic aneurysms.

 

Option C. Atherosclerosis: Atherosclerosis is a condition characterized by the build-up of plaque within the arterial walls, leading to narrowing and hardening of the arteries. It is a risk factor for abdominal aortic aneurysm but is not classified as a connective tissue disorder.

 

Option D. Scurvy: Scurvy is caused by a deficiency in vitamin C, leading to defective collagen synthesis. While it results in symptoms like mucosal bleeding and poor wound healing, it is not associated with aortic aneurysms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Marfan's Syndrome is a connective tissue disorder closely associated with the development of aortic aneurysms due to the defective fibrillin-1 protein affecting the structural integrity of the aortic wall.

choices.text: It is done as a life-saving measure
It is done so as to enable the patient to use adequate prosthesis for walking
It is done for emotional care and support
It is done for good functionality

questions.text: A person fell from the train and injured his both legs a few years back. The amputation was done as shown in the image. What is the most likely reason for doing such an amputation? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It is done as a life-saving measure

 

In cases of severe traumatic injury, such as a person falling from a train and suffering significant leg injuries, amputation is often performed as a life-saving measure. When a limb is crushed, it can lead to a crush syndrome, where the release of myoglobin and potassium from the damaged muscles into the bloodstream can cause acute tubular necrosis of the kidneys and hyperkalemia, leading to fatal arrhythmias. To prevent these life-threatening complications, immediate amputation of the crushed limb is necessary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. It is done so as to enable the patient to use adequate prosthesis for walking: While amputations are sometimes performed with prosthetic use in mind, this is not the primary consideration in emergency situations involving severe trauma.

 

Option C. It is done for emotional care and support: Amputation is not performed for emotional care; it is a surgical intervention aimed at addressing severe physical injuries.

 

Option D. It is done for good functionality: Functionality considerations, such as optimizing the stump for prosthetic fitting, are secondary to the immediate need to save the patient’s life in cases of severe trauma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the context of severe limb trauma, such as a crush injury, amputation is primarily performed as a life-saving measure to prevent complications like crush syndrome and its associated risks.

questions.text: Which of the following vitamins can be synthesized by intestinal bacteria in sufficient amounts to meet body requirements? [NEET PG 2015]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Vitamin K

 

  • Vitamin K exists in at least two major forms - vitamin K₁ and vitamin K₂. Vitamin K₂ is synthesized by intestinal bacteria, which usually provides an adequate supply for human needs. 
  • The bacterial synthesis in the intestine typically meets the body's vitamin K requirements, making it unique among vitamins in this regard.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin B12: While bacteria in the colon synthesize vitamin B12, this synthesis is not sufficient to meet human requirements. The fact that strict vegetarians develop B12 deficiency confirms that intestinal synthesis alone is inadequate.

 

Option C. Vitamin A: Vitamin A is obtained from animal sources as preformed vitamin A (retinol) and from plant sources as provitamins (carotenes). There is no significant bacterial synthesis of vitamin A in the intestines.

 

Option D. Vitamin B1 (Thiamine): Thiamine must be obtained from dietary sources like cereals, pulses, and yeast. Intestinal bacteria do not synthesize significant amounts of thiamine.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Intestinal bacteria normally produce adequate vitamin K₂ for body requirements, which explains why long-term antibiotic therapy that suppresses normal gut flora can lead to vitamin K deficiency.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman diagnosed with schizophrenia had been compliant with her prescribed olanzapine for several months. However, she discontinued the treatment. Which of the following is the most likely reason for her discontinuation? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Weight gain

 

Olanzapine is known to cause significant weight gain and metabolic side effects. In fact, among atypical antipsychotics, olanzapine causes the second-highest weight gain (after clozapine). This metabolic side effect is often a major reason for treatment discontinuation in patients, especially young women who may be concerned about body image and health implications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tardive dyskinesia (TD): Incorrect because atypical antipsychotics like olanzapine have a very low propensity for causing tardive dyskinesia compared to typical antipsychotics. Olanzapine in particular has a very low propensity for TD.

 

Option C. Acute dystonia: Incorrect because acute dystonia is usually caused by typical antipsychotics, particularly with parenteral administration. It is unlikely with olanzapine.

 

Option D. Akathisia: Incorrect because among atypical antipsychotics, aripiprazole is more likely to cause akathisia. Olanzapine is not particularly associated with this side effect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Weight gain is a significant side effect of olanzapine (second highest among atypical antipsychotics after clozapine) and is often a major reason for treatment non-compliance, especially in young patients.

choices.text: It is made from cat gut
It is made from rabbit gut
It is absorbed by enzymatic degradation and macrophage phagocytosis
It is tanned with nickel salts to improve handling and to resist degradation in tissue

questions.text: Which of the following is true about chromic catgut? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. It is absorbed by enzymatic degradation and macrophage phagocytosis.

 

True. Chromic catgut is an absorbable suture, which means that it gets absorbed by the body over time. The process involves enzymatic degradation (breaking down by enzymes) and phagocytosis by macrophages (special cells that engulf and digest foreign substances, microbes, and cellular debris).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is made from cat gut: While the term "catgut" might suggest that the material is derived from cats, this is a misnomer. Catgut suture material is historically derived from the submucosal layer of sheep or goat intestines. The term is a shortened version of the word "cattlegut."

 

Option B. It is made from rabbit gut: This statement is also misleading. As mentioned, the primary sources for catgut are sheep and goat intestines, not rabbit.

 

Option D. It is tanned with nickel salts to improve handling and to resist degradation in tissue: This statement is inaccurate in the context of chromic catgut. Chromic catgut is treated with chromium salts, not nickel salts. Chromium salts are used to cross-link the collagen fibers in the catgut, which increases its resistance to degradation, thus prolonging its time before being absorbed in the tissue. This treatment also improves the suture's handling properties.

 

Educational Objective:


Chromic catgut is an absorbable suture material derived from sheep or goat intestines and is absorbed in the body through enzymatic degradation and macrophage phagocytosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is responsible for the negative charge in fibrinopeptide A? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aspartate and Glutamate

 

Aspartate and glutamate are both acidic amino acids that contain a carboxylic acid group in their side chains. This carboxylic acid group can ionize in solution to release a hydrogen ion, resulting in a negative charge. The negative charges on the aspartate and glutamate residues in fibrinopeptide A contribute to the overall negative charge of the peptide.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Histidine and lysine are positively charged amino acids that can form ionic bonds with negatively charged molecules, but they do not contribute to the negative charge of the peptide.

 

Options A and D Valine and serine are non-polar and uncharged amino acids that do not contribute to the negative charge of the peptide.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fibrinopeptide A is a peptide that is cleaved from fibrinogen during blood clotting to form fibrin. Fibrin is a key component of blood clots and is responsible for stopping bleeding from injured blood vessels. Fibrinopeptide A contains a negative charge due to the presence of aspartate and glutamate residues.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female comes to the OPD with complaints of “feeling tensed” and having “stomach upset” symptoms, including heartburn and diarrhea. She states that she has been having these symptoms since she was 25 years old and that her family members are also usually tense and “nervous.” Which of the following symptoms are also likely to be present in this patient? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tingling of extremities

 

The patient presents with symptoms of anxiety, including constant feelings of tension, gastrointestinal symptoms like heartburn and diarrhea, and a family history of similar symptoms, suggesting a diagnosis of Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD). GAD often includes somatic symptoms, such as tingling of the extremities, due to hyperventilation or heightened nervous system activity associated with anxiety.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ideas of Reference: This symptom is typically associated with psychotic disorders, such as schizophrenia or delusional disorders, where the patient believes that events, objects, or other people have a special and personal significance. This is not characteristic of GAD.

 

Option C. Hallucinations: Hallucinations involve sensory perceptions without external stimuli and are common in psychotic disorders, such as schizophrenia, but not in anxiety disorders.

 

Option D. Neologisms: Neologisms are newly coined words or phrases that have meaning only to the person using them and are commonly seen in formal thought disorders like schizophrenia. This is not a symptom seen in GAD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients with Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD) may experience somatic symptoms like tingling of extremities due to heightened anxiety and nervous system activity.

choices.text: Pedicled TRAM based on superior epigastric artery
Free TRAM based on inferior epigastric artery
DIEP based on deep inferior epigastric artery

questions.text: Identify the false statement about the flaps used in breast reconstruction?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) DIEP is a myocutaneous flap

 

Explanation:

 

The Deep Inferior Epigastric Perforator (DIEP) flap is a type of breast reconstruction flap that is derived from the deep inferior epigastric artery. The DIEP flap is a muscle-sparing flap, meaning it involves only the removal of skin, fat, and blood vessels (perforators), without taking any of the rectus abdominis muscle. This reduces the risk of post-operative abdominal weakness and complications, unlike the Transverse Rectus Abdominis Myocutaneous (TRAM) flap, which includes muscle. Therefore, it is incorrect to refer to the DIEP flap as a myocutaneous flap because it does not include muscle.

 

DIEP is a myocutaneous flap: This statement is false. A myocutaneous flap includes muscle tissue, whereas the DIEP flap spares the rectus abdominis muscle, utilizing only the skin, fat, and perforator vessels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pedicled TRAM based on superior epigastric artery: The pedicled TRAM flap stands for Transverse Rectus Abdominis Myocutaneous flap. It relies on the superior epigastric artery for blood supply, which remains attached (pedicled) to its original source. The flap, including the rectus muscle, is tunneled under the skin to the chest to reconstruct the breast. This statement is accurate.

 

Option B. Free TRAM based on inferior epigastric artery: The free TRAM flap involves the removal of a section of the abdominal tissue, including the rectus muscle, along with the inferior epigastric arteries. This flap is transplanted to the chest and connected to the chest's blood vessels using microsurgical techniques. This flap utilizes both the superior and inferior epigastric arteries. This statement is accurate.

 

Option C. DIEP based on deep inferior epigastric artery: The DIEP flap is similar to the free TRAM flap but does not involve the removal of the rectus muscle. Instead, it uses only the skin, fat, and perforator blood vessels based on the deep inferior epigastric artery. This design spares the abdominal muscles, reducing post-operative complications. This statement is accurate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The DIEP flap is a muscle-sparing flap used in breast reconstruction, involving the skin, fat, and blood vessels without including muscle tissue, which differentiates it from a myocutaneous flap like the TRAM flap.

questions.text: All of the following parameters have a Bishop’s Score of 3 except: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Soft Consistency

 

The question asks for the parameter that does NOT have a Bishop's Score of 3. Reviewing the Bishop's scoring system, cervical consistency rated as "Soft" is assigned a score of 2, not 3. The other parameters listed in the options (5+ dilatation, +2 station, and >80% effacement) all correctly receive a score of 3 according to the Bishop's scoring system.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 5+ Dilatation: The Bishop's score assigns 5+ cm dilatation a score of 3, making this statement correct.

 

Option C. +2 head station: The Bishop's score assigns station +1,+2 a score of 3, making this statement correct.

 

Option D. >80 percent Effacement: The Bishop's score assigns effacement ≥80% a score of 3, making this statement correct.

 

Visual Support

 

The Bishop's score parameters:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the Bishop's scoring system, cervical consistency is scored differently than other parameters, with "Soft" receiving a maximum score of 2, unlike dilatation, effacement, and station which can receive scores of 3.

questions.text: A patient had a cataract surgery 3 years back, now complains of decrease in vision and presented with the following slit lamp image. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Posterior capsular opacification


Posterior capsular opacification (PCO) is the most common complication occurring after cataract surgery. It is often referred to as an "after cataract" or "secondary cataract." PCO develops when lens epithelial cells remaining after surgery migrate and proliferate on the posterior capsule, which eventually leads to clouding.

 

The clinical presentation typically involves gradual vision loss without pain, as seen in this case. The slit lamp image provided shows an intraocular lens in place with opacification of the posterior capsule, which confirms the diagnosis of PCO.

 

The standard treatment for PCO is Nd:YAG laser capsulotomy, a simple and effective procedure to restore vision.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pseudophakic Bullous Keratopathy: This condition occurs due to endothelial cell loss following cataract surgery, leading to corneal decompensation and formation of painful bullae on the corneal surface. It presents with pain and redness in the eye, which is not observed in this patient.

 

 

Option C. Corneal dystrophy: Corneal dystrophy is a genetic disorder that usually presents bilaterally and is unrelated to cataract surgery. It does not cause symptoms similar to those seen in this case and would not present specifically in one eye following cataract surgery.

 

 

Option D. Posterior Subcapsular Cataract: This type of cataract develops in the back of the lens before surgery and is not seen after cataract surgery. Once removed during cataract surgery, posterior subcapsular cataracts do not recur.

 

 

Educational Objective:


Posterior capsular opacification is a common complication after cataract surgery, presenting with gradual vision loss without pain. It is treated with ND laser capsulotomy.

questions.text: Coral red fluorescence on Wood's lamp seen in which of the following conditions? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Erythrasma

 

Explanation:

 

The correct answer is erythrasma.

 

Erythrasma is caused by Corynebacterium minutissimum and typically presents as hyperpigmented patches in skin folds, such as the axilla and toe web spaces. When examined under a Wood's lamp, which emits ultraviolet light at a wavelength of 365 nanometers, erythrasma exhibits a characteristic coral red fluorescence due to the porphyrins produced by the bacteria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitiligo: Under a Wood's lamp, vitiligo shows a milky white fluorescence. This is due to the absence of melanin in the depigmented areas of the skin.

 

Option C. Pityriasis versicolor: Caused by the yeast Malassezia furfur, this condition shows a yellow fluorescence under a Wood's lamp.

 

Option D. Acanthosis nigricans: This condition does not exhibit any fluorescence under a Wood's lamp. It presents with hyperpigmentation and a velvety texture, particularly in skin folds.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Erythrasma, caused by Corynebacterium minutissimum, presents with coral red fluorescence under a Wood's lamp, distinguishing it from other dermatological conditions that may exhibit different types of fluorescence or none at all.

questions.text: Which of the following is an absolute contraindication to OCP use? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thromboembolism

 

Thromboembolism is an absolute contraindication to the use of Oral Contraceptive Pills (OCPs). The use of combined oral contraceptives (COCs) can significantly increase the risk of venous thromboembolism, particularly in individuals with a history of thromboembolic events or known thrombogenic mutations.

 

Absolute Contraindications of Combined OCPs according to the WHO Medical Eligibility Criteria:

 

  • MEC Category 4: Unacceptable health risk if the method is used.
    • Breastfeeding and < 6 weeks postpartum
    • Not breastfeeding; < 21 days postpartum with risk factors for Venous Thromboembolism
    • Age ≥ 35 years with smoking ≥ 15 cigarettes/day
    • Hypertension with systolic BP ≥ 160 OR Diastolic BP ≥ 100 mmHg
    • Hypertension with vascular disease
    • History of DVT/Pulmonary embolism
    • Acute DVT/Pulmonary embolism
    • DVT/Pulmonary embolism on anticoagulant therapy
    • Major surgery with prolonged immobilization
    • Known thrombogenic mutations (e.g., Factor V Leiden, prothrombin mutation, protein S, C, antithrombin deficiency)
    • Current and history of ischemic heart disease
    • Stroke (history of cerebrovascular disease)
    • Complicated valvular heart disease
    • Antiphospholipid Antibody Syndrome
    • Migraine with aura (any age)
    • Current breast cancer
    • Severe cirrhosis
    • Hepatocellular adenoma/carcinoma

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chronic Renal Disease: Chronic renal disease is not an absolute contraindication but requires careful consideration depending on the severity and associated conditions.

 

Option C. History of Amenorrhea: A history of amenorrhea is not an absolute contraindication to the use of OCPs.

 

Option D. Diabetes Mellitus: Diabetes mellitus is not an absolute contraindication. However, it requires careful monitoring, especially if the patient has vascular complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thromboembolism is an absolute contraindication to the use of combined oral contraceptives (COCs) due to the increased risk of venous thromboembolism associated with these medications.

questions.text: Identify the instrument: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nasopharyngeal airway

 

The instrument shown in the image is a nasopharyngeal airway (NPA). This is a flexible, soft tube that is inserted through the nostril into the nasopharynx to secure an open airway. NPAs are particularly useful in situations where the patient is conscious or semi-conscious and may not tolerate an oropharyngeal airway due to a gag reflex. It is also useful when the oral route is not accessible or practical.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oropharyngeal airway:

 

 

Option B. Ovassapian airway:  The Ovassapian airway is a specific type of oropharyngeal airway designed for fiberoptic intubation.

 

 

Option D. Uncuffed endotracheal tube

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The nasopharyngeal airway (NPA) is a flexible tube used to secure an airway via the nasal passage, especially in patients who are semi-conscious and have an intact gag reflex.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male patient has been diagnosed with hypertension. On examination, there is no existing cardiovascular disease, no hypertension-mediated organ damage (HMOD), and the renal function is normal. He should be immediately started on pharmacological management if his blood pressure is more than: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. > 160/100 mmHg

 

  • The ISH (International society of HTN) 2020 guidelines were made to help decision making in low-middle income countries.
  • Presence of ASCVD risk factors, HMOD (HTN mediated organ damage) is an indication to start anti-HTN therapy.
  • Home BP recording helps in diagnosis of Masked HTN, rule out white-coat effect
  • ABPM provides 24-hour trend and fluctuations in BP.

 

 

Home BP > 135/85 mmHg = HTN

 

ABPM cutoffs:

 

  1. Mean Awake (daytime) average ≥ 135/85 mmHg
  2. 24h average ≥ 130/80 mmHg
  3. Mean Asleep(night) ≥ 120/70 mmHg

 

BP drops at night by (10-20%), morning surge – Steep increase, peaks in late afternoon.
 

Best observed in ABPM (Ambulatory BP monitoring):

 

  • Normal Dip: 10-20 % at night
  • Extreme Dip > 20%
  • Non-dippers < 10% (A/w Activation of RAAS)
  • Risers: BP raise

 

Note: Increase mortality risk among Non-Dippers and Risers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Immediate pharmacological treatment for hypertension in patients without additional cardiovascular risk factors or organ damage should commence when blood pressure levels exceed 160/100 mmHg, according to the ISH 2020 guidelines. This approach helps to target treatment to those most likely to benefit from immediate intervention, balancing the benefits and risks of pharmacotherapy.

 

Reference: ISH2020, AHA2017 HTN guidelines

questions.text: The sensory area marked in the image is primarily innervated by which nerve? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Radial nerve 

 

The area marked in the image is supplied by radial nerve.

 

 

  • Origin: Arises from the posterior cord of the brachial plexus.
  • Main Functions: Primarily a motor nerve for the extensor muscles of the arm and forearm. It also has sensory branches for the skin on the back of the hand and the posterior arm and forearm.
  • Motor Innervation: Triceps brachii, anconeus, brachioradialis, and all the extensor muscles in the forearm.
  • Sensory Innervation: Supplies the posterior surface of the arm and forearm, and the radial aspect of the dorsum of the hand.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Posterior Interosseous Nerve (PIN):

 

  • Origin: It's a continuation of the deep branch of the radial nerve.
  • Main Functions: Purely motor nerve that supplies the extensor muscles of the forearm.
  • Motor Innervation: All the deep extensors of the forearm, including extensor pollicis longus, extensor pollicis brevis, extensor indicis, and others.
  • Sensory Innervation: The PIN does not have a sensory function.

 

Option C. Median Nerve:

 

  • Origin: Formed by the union of the medial and lateral roots from the brachial plexus.
  • Main Functions: Supplies most of the flexor muscles in the forearm and some muscles in the hand.
  • Motor Innervation: Flexor muscles in the anterior forearm (except flexor carpi ulnaris and the ulnar half of flexor digitorum profundus) and thenar muscles and first two lumbricals in the hand.
  • Sensory Innervation: Palmar aspect of the lateral three and a half fingers and the associated palm area.

 

Option D. Ulnar Nerve:

 

  • Origin: Arises from the medial cord of the brachial plexus.
  • Main Functions: Supplies muscles in the hand and a few in the forearm.
  • Motor Innervation: Flexor carpi ulnaris and the ulnar half of flexor digitorum profundus in the forearm. In the hand, it supplies most intrinsic muscles, including the hypothenar muscles, the palmar and dorsal interossei, and the third and fourth lumbricals.
  • Sensory Innervation: Provides sensation to the palmar and dorsal aspects of the medial one and a half fingers and the associated hand region.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sensory function of the radial nerve is provided by its four main sensory branches:

 

  • Inferior lateral cutaneous nerve of the arm: Supplies the lateral aspect of the anterior upper arm between the deltoid and the elbow.
  • Posterior cutaneous nerve of the arm: Supplies part of the posterior aspect of the upper arm.
  • Posterior cutaneous nerve of the forearm: Supplies a tapered strip of the middle portion of the posterior forearm.
  • Superficial branch of the radial nerve: Supplies the posterior surface of the lateral 3 ½ digits and the associated areas of the palm.

choices.text: Supposititious child

questions.text: A woman gave birth to twins belonging to two different fathers. This case would be best described as? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Superfecundation

 

  • Similarities between Superfecundation and superfetation:
    • In both there is fertilization of 2 ova from 2 separate acts of coitus 
    • So twin pregnancy in both
    • Fathers can be different for the two babies in both Superfecundation and superfetation
  • Differences between Superfecundation and superfetation:
    • In Superfecundation the two acts of coitus occurred in same menstrual cycle, whereas in superfetation in two different cycles.
    • Hence, in Superfecundation both fetuses have similar development, and born at same time, whereas, in superfetation, the first fetus is more developed, and also, they may not be born at same time.

 

In the question, it is mentioned that “woman gave birth to twins”, which implies that both babies were born at same time. Hence superfecundation is a better choice than superfetation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superfetation: Fertilization of a second ovum during a different menstrual cycle while a pregnancy is already ongoing. The first fetus is more developed than the second, and they may not be born at the same time.

 

Option C. Supposititious children are fraudulent offspring. These arose when an heir was required and so a suitable baby might be procured and passed off as genuine.

 

Option D. Atavism: A modification of a biological structure whereby an ancestral genetic trait reappears after having been lost through evolutionary change in previous generations. E.g. tail in humans

 

Educational Objective:

 

Superfecundation refers to the fertilization of two ova from separate acts of coitus within the same menstrual cycle, resulting in the birth of twins that can have different fathers and are born at the same time.

choices.text: Competitively blocking the binding of ACh to its receptors
Repetitive stimulation of ACh receptors on muscle endplate
Inhibiting the calcium channels on presynaptic membrane

questions.text: Mechanism of action of the curare group of muscle relaxants is?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Competitively blocking the binding of ACh to its receptors 

 

  • The curare group of muscle relaxants are non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agents.
  • These drugs act by binding to the acetylcholine (ACh) receptors at the neuromuscular junction without activating them.
  • This competitive inhibition prevents acetylcholine from binding to its receptors, thereby inhibiting the action of acetylcholine and leading to muscle paralysis.
  • This prevents the muscle from contracting, resulting in muscle relaxation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Persistently depolarizing at neuromuscular junction: This describes depolarizing muscle relaxants, such as succinylcholine, which bind to and open the acetylcholine receptors on the muscle endplate. This causes a prolonged depolarization and prevents the muscle from repolarizing, thereby causing paralysis.

 

Option C. Repetitive stimulation of ACh receptors on muscle endplate: This does not describe the mechanism of any muscle relaxant. Persistent or repetitive stimulation would cause sustained depolarization leading to muscle paralysis, but this is not how the curare group works.

 

Option D. Inhibiting the calcium channels on presynaptic membrane: Some drugs inhibit calcium channels, preventing the release of neurotransmitters, including acetylcholine. However, this is not the mechanism of action of the curare group of muscle relaxants.

 

Educational Objective :

 

  • The curare group of muscle relaxants work by competitively blocking the binding of acetylcholine to its receptors at the neuromuscular junction, leading to muscle paralysis.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 779

questions.text: When a codon is changed to stop codon, then it is: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Non-sense mutation

 

Amino acid codon is replaced by a stop codon causing premature termination of translation and truncated protein

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stop Codons mutation: There are specific codons known as "stop codons" that signal the termination of protein synthesis. These stop codons include UAA, UAG, and UGA. When a ribosome encounters a stop codon, it releases the newly synthesized protein, and protein synthesis comes to an end.

 

Option C. Mis-sense mutation: Codon for one amino acid is replaced by another amino acid codon causing change in protein properties.

 

Option D. Silent mutation: Codon is changed but amino acid is not changed due to codon degeneracy, so no effect on resulting protein.    

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 396

questions.text: What is the management of choice for aneurysms performed by interventional radiologists? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Coiling

 

The management of choice for aneurysms by interventional radiologists is coiling. This minimally invasive procedure involves the insertion of platinum coils into the aneurysm through an endovascular route. The coils promote clotting within the aneurysm, effectively reducing the risk of rupture and stabilizing the aneurysm.

 

Coiling is performed under the guidance of digital subtraction angiography (DSA), which allows the radiologist to visualize the blood vessels and accurately place the coils within the aneurysm. This technique has become the gold standard for treating cerebral aneurysms due to its minimally invasive nature and high success rate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clipping: This is a surgical procedure where a neurosurgeon places a clip at the neck of the aneurysm to prevent blood flow into it. While effective, it is more invasive than coiling and typically not performed by interventional radiologists.

 

Option C. Nimodipine: Nimodipine is a calcium channel blocker used to prevent vasospasm following subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH). It is not a treatment for aneurysms but a supportive therapy to prevent complications.

 

Option D. Angioplasty: Angioplasty is used to widen narrowed or obstructed blood vessels, often in cases of peripheral arterial disease. It is not a primary treatment for aneurysms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coiling is the preferred management for aneurysms performed by interventional radiologists, involving the insertion of coils to promote clotting and stabilize the aneurysm.
